content: When my wife and I held our handfasting ceremony in New Hampshire, we definitely brought a lot to the local economy. First, we rented out the carriage house and garden area from a beautiful local inn for the ceremony and reception. We also rented the groundkeeper's apartment and gardener's room above the carriage house for our stay. We ordered catering from the inn. We bought a huge tray of canolis from an Italian bakery in Boston's North End. While this was a hometown wedding for me, it was a destination wedding for my wife. We bought plane tickets for ourselves, and all of my wife's family (including cousins, aunts, uncles, in-laws, and several of our close friends) bought plane tickets and rental vehicles to travel from the midwest to New Hampshire. Then, of course, they all rented hotel rooms for the course of their stay. People bought wedding gifts, souvenirs, and other things. They also patronized many local restaurants, museums, and other establishments during their stay. While our actual wedding only cost between two and three thousand dollars (dresses, rental location, catering, and decorations), we probably brought over $30,000 to the area between all our family members and ourselves. Additionally, young gay couples are often dual-income-no-kids households, and have more expendable income. If such a couple moves to an area, they'll buy stuff, pay taxes, and are less likely to have children who will drain off the system. If couples are able to support each other better, such as being able to let one person be placed on the other person's health insurance plan, then you have fewer uninsured people who end up going on state health insurance programs. There you go - even LESS of a drain on the government! So, never mind just the cost of the weddings... the economic boost is much bigger than that. But the states that have done this aren't just doing it for "revenue." They're doing it because they realize that giving all groups equal rights doesn't diminish the rights of the majority.

It has the LOWEST divorce rate in the country. It has one of the most educated populations, and one of the highest average IQ levels for its citizens. It has a low infant mortality. It has lower obesity rates than much of the nation. It has some of the best universities in the world, and a remarkable number of high-end research facilities. content: When my wife and I held our handfasting ceremony in New Hampshire, we definitely brought a lot to the local economy. First, we rented out the carriage house and garden area from a beautiful local inn for the ceremony and reception. We also rented the groundkeeper's apartment and gardener's room above the carriage house for our stay. We ordered catering from the inn. We bought a huge tray of canolis from an Italian bakery in Boston's North End. While this was a hometown wedding for me, it was a destination wedding for my wife. We bought plane tickets for ourselves, and all of my wife's family (including cousins, aunts, uncles, in-laws, and several of our close friends) bought plane tickets and rental vehicles to travel from the midwest to New Hampshire. Then, of course, they all rented hotel rooms for the course of their stay. People bought wedding gifts, souvenirs, and other things. They also patronized many local restaurants, museums, and other establishments during their stay. While our actual wedding only cost between two and three thousand dollars (dresses, rental location, catering, and decorations), we probably brought over $30,000 to the area between all our family members and ourselves. Additionally, young gay couples are often dual-income-no-kids households, and have more expendable income. If such a couple moves to an area, they'll buy stuff, pay taxes, and are less likely to have children who will drain off the system. If couples are able to support each other better, such as being able to let one person be placed on the other person's health insurance plan, then you have fewer uninsured people who end up going on state health insurance programs. There you go - even LESS of a drain on the government! So, never mind just the cost of the weddings... the economic boost is much bigger than that. But the states that have done this aren't just doing it for "revenue." They're doing it because they realize that giving all groups equal rights doesn't diminish the rights of the majority.
